description: Single-page marketing website explaining the AI Toolkit system for novices to agentic loops and opencode

userStories.title: Hero Section
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to immediately understand what the AI Toolkit is so I can decide if it's relevant to me.
acceptanceCriteria: Subheadline: Brief description (e.g., "57 specialized agents working together to build software")
Primary CTA button links to Getting Started section
Secondary CTA links to GitHub repo (placeholder URL)
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: What Is It Section
userStories.description: As a novice to agentic loops, I want a simple explanation of what the toolkit does so I understand the concept before diving into details.
acceptanceCriteria: Brief explanation of agentic loops / AI agents concept
Explains how the toolkit organizes agents for different tasks
Uses simple language appropriate for beginners
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Primary Agents Overview
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to see the main agents I'd interact with so I understand the entry points to the system.
acceptanceCriteria: Each primary agent has a name and one-line description
Visual distinction showing these are the "main" agents
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Agent Categories with Counts
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to see the categories of sub-agents with counts so I understand the breadth of the system.
acceptanceCriteria: Display agent categories: Critics (22), Developers (9), Testers (5), Other (21)
Each category has a brief description of what those agents do
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Skills Overview
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to see what skills are available so I understand the specialized workflows the toolkit supports.
acceptanceCriteria: Brief explanation of what skills are (specialized workflows agents can load)
List skill categories or example skill names
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Getting Started Section
userStories.description: As a visitor ready to try the toolkit, I want clear step-by-step instructions so I can get set up quickly.
acceptanceCriteria: Step 3: Upgrade GitHub Copilot to Pro Plus for best models
Step 4: Run the setup script in opencode to prepare the environment
Each step is numbered and clearly explained
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Footer with Repo Link
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want a footer with links to the repository so I can explore more.
acceptanceCriteria: GitHub repo link (placeholder URL for now)
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Responsive Layout
userStories.description: As a mobile visitor, I want the page to work well on my phone so I can read about the toolkit anywhere.
acceptanceCriteria: All sections readable on mobile (375px width)
Navigation works on mobile if present
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Dark Mode Toggle
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to toggle between light and dark mode so I can read comfortably in any lighting.
acceptanceCriteria: Toggle button visible in header or floating position
Respects system preference on first load
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Agent Relationship Diagram
userStories.description: As a visitor, I want to see a simple diagram showing how primary agents delegate to sub-agents so I understand the system architecture at a glance.
acceptanceCriteria: Simple diagram showing primary agents (bildr, ralph, planner, etc.) at top
Arrows or lines showing delegation to sub-agent categories (critics, devs, testers)
Clean, minimal visual style (not overly complex)
Works as SVG or CSS-based (no heavy image files)
Works in both light and dark mode

userStories.title: Static Export for GitHub Pages
userStories.description: As a developer, I need the site to build as static HTML so it can be hosted on GitHub Pages.
acceptanceCriteria: No server-side features that break static export
